newsitem.title: USA: $4.4 bln erroneously claimed in '94 tax credit - IRS.
newsitem.headline: $4.4 bln erroneously claimed in '94 tax credit - IRS.

text.p: About $4.4 billion, or one-fourth of the Earned Income Tax Credit for low-income workers claimed for 1994, was erroneous, an Internal Revenue Service report said Wednesday.

"The study found that taxpayers erroneously claimed approximately $4.4 billion of EITC, which was 25.8 percent of the total EITC claimed," IRS Commissioner Margaret Richardson wrote in a letter to Rep. Nancy Johnson, a Connecticut Republican.
The study was based on a sample of 1994 returns claiming the tax credit and accepted by the IRS in the first four months of 1995.
Richardson called the noncompliance rate "unacceptably high" but said the study indicated "significant improvement" since the late 1980s.
House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Bill Archer, a Texas Republican, said he intended to hold a hearing on the report.

"Today's revelation is extremely troubling," Archer said in a statement. "Despite the government's best efforts, EITC fraud is shockingly high, making it one of the most abused programs on the books," he said.
